Gordon,

Do you mean Jochiku?

Murakami school did cross my mind, but for sure they're not at that level.

Jim





  Hi Ron and Jim,

  Having seen the menuki, I would agree to the late Edo call. Also,
  dragonflies are a favorite motif of Jakushi, but these do not come up to his
  level of workmanship. This makes a call really hard, as Jim says, so,
  Kyo-Kinko is the attribution of last resort.

  Gordon

  -----Original Message-----
  From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
  Behalf Of Jim Gilbert
  Sent: Thursday, February 28, 2008 9:58 AM
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kyo-kinko

  Ron,
  I didn't say it was hard to date Kyo-kinko, just impossible to assign to a
  group. There aren't different attributions for the different parts of the
  Edo period. The NTHK does assign a period within Edo for every fitting or
  koshirae paper:

  $B=i4|(B Shoki (the beginning)

  $BA04|(B Zenki (the first part)

  $BCf4|(B Chuki (the middle)

  $B8e4|(B Koki (late)

  $BKv4|(B Baki (the end)

  The NBTHK does not.

  I can't even guess at a group on the tombo menuki, and that is the way it is
  with the Kyo-kinko attribution. I didn't see them in Tampa, but based on the
  photos they look like late Edo work.

  Agreed with Gordon's earlier comment that there are plenty of early solid
  gold menuki, including Ko-mino and Ko-Kinko work in addition to Goto. The
  recent NBTHK AB display and lecture at Tampa included several pairs of solid
  gold mainline Goto menuki from the Muromachi and early Edo periods.

  Jim

  ----- Original Message -----
  From: Ron Hartmann
  To: nihontostudy@ <mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com> yahoogroups.com
  Sent: Wednesday, February 27, 2008 7:31 PM
  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kyo-kinko

  Jim -

  You may have seen these in Tampa but here is a link showing the menuki that
  I was asking about:
  http://www.nihonto. <http://www.nihonto.com/11.3.07.html> com/11.3.07.html

  Papered as Kyo-kinko, maybe these fall into that area as you mentioned where
  it is difficult to "date" them or to assign a maker. Can you comment on
  these that I purchased? Work seems very nice to my eye and I'm certainly
  happy with them.

  Ron
  STL

  ----- Original Message -----
  From: Jim Gilbert
  To: nihontostudy@ <mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com> yahoogroups.com
  Sent: Wednesday, February 27, 2008 5:36 PM
  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kyo-kinko

  Kyo-kinko is non-Goto (non-Mino, etc.) kinko work from after the Momoyama
  period. It is often applied to work that is in Goto style but is not Goto
  main or sideline work. Edo-kinko used to be used similarly for work in the
  style of Edo region machibori kinko schools, but lately this is generally
  lumped as "Kyo-kinko" as well. So it truly is a grab bag, but the problem
  (especially with menuki) is that there is so much Edo period kinko work with
  no unique character to it that makes it possible to give a more specific
  attribution.

  BTW, generic Edo period kinko work of lower quality than Kyo-kinko is
  attributed to Kyo-kanagushi.

  Jim

  ----- Original Message -----
  From: ROBSON Gordon
  To: nihontostudy@ <mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com> yahoogroups.com
  Sent: Wednesday, February 27, 2008 4:23 PM
  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kyo-kinko

  Hi Ron,

  My understanding is that Kyo-Kinko is the new name for Waki-Goto. This would

  make them a grab bag like Ko-Kinko or even Shoami. Their dates are post-Ko-
  Kinko, so early Edo to Bakumatsu. There is a Kyo-Kinko book out there. I
  think the
  title is Kyo-Kinko no Kenkyu (research into Kyo-Kinko) or something like
  that. Jim
  is probably better up on this stuff then I am.

  On on different note, good luck to Harry. Honto ni gambatte kudasai!!

  Gordon
